title: 'Mirror Touch' and the Neural Basis of Empathy (Response to: Society, Social Behaviour and the Neurosciences)
abstractText: 'Mirror neurons' respond both when a person performs an action and when observing another person performing the same action. Comparable systems have been documented for pain, emotions and sensations (eg touch).  This has been linked to empathy, conceptually, because it suggests that there is a common system for dealing both with our own current state and those of other people. We may, in some literal sense, share the feelings of others because of a shared neural circuitry for self and other.  For a small number of people, seeing touch does trigger conscious tactile experiences on their own body - 'mirror touch synaesthesia'.   This appears to be linked with heightened empathy.  This ESRC-funded research project will investigate the cognitive, affective and neural mechanisms of the tactile mirror system.  The operation of this system will be explored in the normal population and those with mirror-touch synaesthesia.  The research will consider the following: how different spatial frames of reference map between self and other; how the tactile mirror system is affected by touch to different people/objects; how individual differences in this system are linked with measures of empathy; and what distinguishes conscious from unconscious ‘mirrored’ percepts.
